questions.text: In the case of prolonged corticosteroid therapy for a pregnant lady, the preferred corticosteroid is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prednisolone Prednisolone appears safer than D exa/ BetaMethasone because Prednisolone is metabolized by the placenta and thereby reduces fetal exposure.

Highyeild:

Use of Corticosteroids in pregnant women Foetal abnormalities: Cleft palate and other defects are produced in animals but have not been encountered in clinical use in pregnant women. The risk of abortion, stillbirth, or neonatal death is not increased, but intrauterine growth retardation can occur after prolonged therapy, and neurological/behavioral disturbances in the offspring are feared. Prednisolone appears safer than dexa/betamethasone because it is metabolized by the placenta , reducing fetal exposure. There is no evidence of fetal growth retardation occurring after short-term use in the mother. Prolonged corticosteroid therapy during pregnancy increases the risk of gestational diabetes, pregnancy-induced hypertension, and preeclampsia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female was planned to start on corticosteroids for ulcerative colitis for 6 months. The patient was told not to stop the drug suddenly. Which of the following Measures will not minimize the risk of HPA axis suppression?

options.label: B
options.text: Use topical or local steroid preparations wherever possible

options.label: C
options.text: Give the dose divided three times daily so that peak steroid concentration is reduced

options.label: D
options.text: Switch to alternate-day therapy if possible

questions.correct_answer: C. Give the dose divided three times daily so that peak steroid concentration is reduced
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Give the dose divided three times daily so that peak steroid concentration is reduced Will produce marked suppression of the HPA (Hypothalamo-Pituitary-Adrenal) axis.

Highyeild:

HPA axis suppression risk occurs in the person receiving Hydrocortisone 20-25mg/day or equivalent for longer than 2-3 weeks . Such patients may need protection with a corticosteroid (oral or i.v.) if a stressful situation develops up to one year after withdrawal. Administration of ACTH during withdrawal does not hasten recovery because it has been found that adrenals recover earlier than the pituitary and hypothalamus If a patient on corticosteroid therapy develops an infection -the steroid should not be discontinued despite its propensity to weaken host defense and delay healing. Rather, the dose may have to be increased to meet the stress of infection. Surgery in such a patient should be covered by intraoperative and postoperative i.v. hydrocortisone till the condition stabilizes, followed by oral prednisolone. Measures that minimize HPA axis suppression are: Use shorter-acting steroids (hydrocortisone, prednisolone) at the lowest possible dose. Use steroids for the shortest period possible. Give the entire daily dose at one time in the morning. Switch to alternate-day therapy if the condition does not deteriorate on the ‘off’ day. It has been found that a moderate dose of a short-acting steroid (e.g. prednisolone) given at 48 hr intervals did not cause HPA suppression, whereas the same total amount given in 4 divided 12 hourly doses produced marked HPA suppression. Alternate-day therapy also resulted in less immunological suppression -lower risk of infection. The longer-acting steroids (dexamethasone , etc.) are not suitable for alternate-day therapy. The only problem with alternate-day therapy is that many steroid-dependent patients are incapacitated on the ‘off day’. If appropriate, use local (dermal, inhaled, ocular, nasal, rectal, intrasynovial) preparations of a steroid with poor systemic availability (beclomethasone dipropionate, triamcinolone acetonide, fluticasone, etc.).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Optionsl A, B, & D. will minimize the risk of HPA axis suppression.

questions.text: A 67-year-old with Cushing disease due to ACTH-producing pituitary tumors. He could not be operated on for a tumor due to comorbid conditions. He needs to be started on a drug which is a somatostatin analogue to control hypercortisolism. Which of the following is that drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pasireotide Pasireotide is a somatostatin analogue, that inhibits ACTH secretion and reduces the circulating levels of cortisol in patients with ACTH-producing pituitary tumors. Pasireotide is FDA-approved for use in those patients with Cushing disease who are not candidates for surgery or who have recurrent disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Mifepristone - is a progesterone receptor antagonist. At higher doses , it inhibits the Glucocorticoid Mifepristone has been granted orphan drug status in the U.S. for the treatment of hyperglycemia secondary to endogenous Cushing syndrome in patients who have type 2 diabetes mellitus or glucose intolerance and have failed surgery or are not candidates for surgery. Option: C. Mitotane is an Adreno-corticolimbic agent used to treat inoperable adrenocortical carcinoma. Its cytolytic action is due to its metabolic conversion to a reactive acyl chloride by adrenal mitochondrial CYPs and subsequent reactivity with cellular proteins . It also inhibits CYP11A1 (cholesterol side-chain cleavage enzyme) , thereby reducing steroid synthesis Option: D. Metyrapone- is a relatively selective inhibitor of 11β-hydroxylase.11β-hydroxylase converts 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol , which is the last step in steroid synthesis. used in hypercorticism resulting from either adrenal neoplasms or tumors producing ACTH ectopically.
